Love this game! Yes its a gatcha game, so you will have to spend some cash.  Only real downside to this game: too many menu's! You can get lost in the menu's sometimes.

It's a hero gatcha-ish game with auto battler, so it's fine for what it is. I didn't finish the storyline, but it seems fine, not terrible, not amazing. You get some character customization with your starting character, and it feels like you can usually get sufficient resources of various kinds just by playing and having patience. Overall, if you want a dnd flavored hero collector, this will do. 

There Are ample opportunities for you to spend money on the game, but I didn't see anything that is locked into a state of 'you can only acquire this by spending real world money'. To compare and contrast with a similar game I played for longer: This game doesn't seem to be introducing limited time acquisition cross over characters that then get power crept by more readily available characters just a few months after they were introduced. So you aren't going to be in a situation like in FFBE where you saved up a bunch of summons and blew them out getting 4 copies of event only gilgamesh only to have his massive combat capability and combo synergy with other characters become mostly irrelevant a few months later. 

At least at the time of the review, you don't have to worry about some limited time cross over summon being a thing, introducing FOMO to you, and then becoming irrelvant even if you went in on them. There aren't any equipment items that only show up in a 'new player welcome package give us 10 dollars' that ify ou miss out you can never acquire again later. You don't have a pop up every single day going 'give us money give us money give us money'.

There's ways to spend money, but the game isn't obnoxious about them. If you want to be able to set up your guys with upgrades and gear and figure out how to combo different characters, their abilities, elements, and play around with synergies and how unit placement might alter the impact of a particular character in battle? This can scratch that itch. You can engage in limited control over the fights (mostly in when characters use their ultimates), but you can also leave it to the auto battle element, minimize the game, let it auto grind some resources out for you while you do other things, and come back to it and use the resources you got from your guys being able to handle things just fine without your direct oversight. 

It's fine, I'd give it a passing grade for being competently made and not obnoxious with the monetization. I didn't put any money into it, and it's a free to play game as baseline, so I feel like checking the 'did you get this product for free' check mark on the review would be misleading to select. Everyone gets it for free, it's not like I was given a review copy.

The story is ok at best, but I was bored through most of the beginning. The camera angle during combat is unchangeable unless I missed something, which can completely block units that you can't see. That makes any manual ability inputs longer/harder to do, especially when there are towering units blocking everything in its way. That forces you to just use auto, which has several issues.
You level up everything simultaneously (Resonance), which is great. I like that concept that removes the need to grind every single unit to make them playable. You just pick up and play with any character. Some micromanage things remain like gear, but the accessibility for casual players is there.
The main issue is that, even without all the free rewards or whatever promotion the game gives, There is no difficulty. I doubt you'd get any real challenge for several hundred hours of gameplay. It's really just click the auto navigate to go straight to the objective, then let auto combat do its thing. It's an idle game that needs your constant attention to keep going once each tasks are completed within 30 seconds. 
Either turn this into a fully idle game or raise the overall difficulty where auto doesn't always automatically succeed.

However, most of the negative reviews can be ignored. There's nothing confusing with the quests, I haven't had any technical issues, and the game can still be enjoyable if you like a basic D&D style of story over thoughtful gameplay. It's clear that the devs enjoyed making the game and put in a lot of silly jokes or unordinary concepts in regards to lore or inconsequential mechanics (like the player turning into a sentient dice), but it feels like they forgot to make the core of the gameplay fun. All the focus went toward pivoting a generic storyline.

This is a gacha game through and through. It even has an annoying energy mechanic and roughly a thousand currencies.

What makes it charming is its ties to D&D, its interesting storyline, and the fact that you needn't spend any money (at least not for the first 20 hours or so, which is pretty good for a fun, free game). I don't know if there's any life in the endgame. As a gacha game, I'd guess there's probably none, but I am willing to take the trip there to find out.

since the re-launch the game is in a much better place. core mechanics are all the same, but its far less grindy than before.
for example, you dont have to individually level up each character so you only run Goblins a handful of times to get your "account" to 100, and all toons are done!

scrolls invested in characters also carry over between seasons now. 
and also very FTP friendly if you put in the work - i finished 18th last season without spending anything

People comparing this game to Raid are plain delusional. There is no greater evil in the gaming industry than Plarium, period.
This game is not perfect, but you can do really well as a free to play.

This game has a very interesting way of taking the salient elements of team build strategy rpg and automating the boring parts to pin point where the fun is. It's got a lot of fun types of combat and open world encounters to keep me coming back. The downside is they bottleneck advancement or levels caps for a couple of days at time. It has a lot of currencies which can get confusing to get stuff for character development.  There is a decent amount of pay to play, but not as bad as other games I've tried. You can get a lot of enjoyment playing for free if you are willing to take your time. 

The strategy has a pretty decent learning curve based on keywords and team builds, but it's rewarding once you figure it out. I'd like to see them remove some of the time periods to advance. I find I have to quit the game and come back the next day when I want to keep playing because all of the content is locked with a timer. I also play more than most people, so that may not be the case for you. 

My suggestion is to try this game. It may surprise you.

If you don't like auto battlers or gacha then this game definitely isn't for you.

I played this in Beta and checked back on it recently ,since it's "revival" just out of pure curiosity. I am ready to finalize my thoughts on this 'piece'.

Dragonheir had a strange niche when it released of being a very self-absorbed, weirdly Western RPG -targeting, P2W gacha in the AFK clone subgenre. It's features and highlights include UI and optimization to elicit a nostalgic 2013 mobile game era that absolutely no one missed. The days of absence of gameplay and graphics, cheap design tools and limited phone power, after one too many rugpulls over the years, the mobile player base has grown up and wisened up to such tactics. Not to understate, how the era involved Western consumer direct exposure to the third world, like breathing in raw sewage while stuck in traffic on your way to work.

There is a real "I designed this, it's my first game" amateurishness about it, which will undoubtedly remind the player of D&D and other D&D sub and off-brand products. But it also tries to "cash in" on D&D revival of the BG3 era of last couple of years, by adding obnoxious dice rolling everywhere. I've never clicked so much since playing Diablo. This is about the only connection to D&D or really any RPG. For the most part, it's a copy&paste Chinese "lower buyer" gacha some 'fan' bought to make his own mobile bestseller. 

Inexplicably, the devs of this masterpiece decided to compound it's problems by borrowing the lesser "multi-server, mmo-style, PoE season" system from the less popular titles in the gacha space. This skinner box feels a LOT like a testing ground for AFK devs to try ideas that they know for certain are doomed to fail, just to make sure they are right, in a live environment.

So, what's "new" in the ressurection? Honestly, I didn't notice much difference. I'm out of the loop on cheap mobile games lately, so I don't know the standard. It's pay to play and once the free currency runs out, you no longer have any reason to keep going. This may very much be the standard nowadays, for all I know. They really expect you to pay for nothing, and they promise not to deliver, cause they game is as unfinished as the beta was, for the most part. This is more or less the experience the first time around, only nice to know that anyone dumb enough to give them money got completely ripped off cause the reset came with a full server wipe, with a maximum of 10 pulls in compensation for playing before, even if you spent a million dollars.

The only real new thing is the new players I guess that are giving it a shot from a new perspective. Some of them seem like they are in the third world. Also there is strange new characters, like the mysteriously overpowered Chinese woman who's superpower is that she's Chinese and is able to solo entire teams, despite being mid-tier according to the official tier lists (which dont even exist.) 

There is really no hope of appealing to any D&D or RPG fan. This is still true, throughout. It's one of those games you can't really critique, because you would just end up critiquing everything ad nauseum. There is so little that it does right, that it's actually a coincidence when you manage to find fun in it. 

It does not surprise me in the slightest, that WoTC, officially partnered with THIS mobile title, of them all. It's actually exactly perfect, in every way, in this regard. How do you make a game so f%*@#() BAD it can't even play itself? This is it, this is the absolute bottom of the gaming barrel, floating in the sea, in the grand interdimensional toilet that they call gacha gaming. 

In summary:
-nothing for gambling addict: no real waifu, no wild chance, very linear and boring
-nothing for grind addict: no real carrot on a stick, unrewarding grinding
-nothing for daily login: 1 pull a month is your motivator, literally 
-none of the promo codes work
-you have to play the (horrible) singleplayer every season, but you dont get the "new player free currency" frontload everytime, which is the only way it can work
-and finally, their one idea which was seasons and retaining your 'collection' they completely dropped the ball on because they did a full wipe of every account in the first year
This game hasn't changed at all, It remains extremely pay-to-win and If you wanna see whales take the best prizes in everything this game offers... feel free to play.

The loss of a major limb causes any creature to bleed out! Not to mention with only 3 heads instead of 5, you've just slashed Tiamat's fighting capacity by a third, and yet you run away?!
Who wrote this garbage?!

But that's all.

Hardly the most involving tactical combat.
Checkers is more tactically demanding.

You mean I have to craft a bunch of stuff that allegedly increases their stat lines, which has no effect on them getting their asses handed to them. Yes, he's equipped.

I played this in Beta and checked back on it recently ,since it's "revival" just out of pure curiosity. I am ready to finalize my thoughts on this 'piece'.

Dragonheir had a strange niche when it released of being a very self-absorbed, weirdly Western RPG -targeting, P2W gacha in the AFK clone subgenre. It's features and highlights include UI and optimization to elicit a nostalgic 2013 mobile game era that absolutely no one missed. The days of absence of gameplay and graphics, cheap design tools and limited phone power, after one too many rugpulls over the years, the mobile player base has grown up and wisened up to such tactics. Not to understate, how the era involved Western consumer direct exposure to the third world, like breathing in raw sewage while stuck in traffic on your way to work.

There is a real "I designed this, it's my first game" amateurishness about it, which will undoubtedly remind the player of D&D and other D&D sub and off-brand products. But it also tries to "cash in" on D&D revival of the BG3 era of last couple of years, by adding obnoxious dice rolling everywhere. I've never clicked so much since playing Diablo. This is about the only connection to D&D or really any RPG. For the most part, it's a copy&paste Chinese "lower buyer" gacha some 'fan' bought to make his own mobile bestseller. 

Inexplicably, the devs of this masterpiece decided to compound it's problems by borrowing the lesser "multi-server, mmo-style, PoE season" system from the less popular titles in the gacha space. This skinner box feels a LOT like a testing ground for AFK devs to try ideas that they know for certain are doomed to fail, just to make sure they are right, in a live environment.

So, what's "new" in the ressurection? Honestly, I didn't notice much difference. I'm out of the loop on cheap mobile games lately, so I don't know the standard. It's pay to play and once the free currency runs out, you no longer have any reason to keep going. This may very much be the standard nowadays, for all I know. They really expect you to pay for nothing, and they promise not to deliver, cause they game is as unfinished as the beta was, for the most part. This is more or less the experience the first time around, only nice to know that anyone dumb enough to give them money got completely ripped off cause the reset came with a full server wipe, with a maximum of 10 pulls in compensation for playing before, even if you spent a million dollars.

The only real new thing is the new players I guess that are giving it a shot from a new perspective. Some of them seem like they are in the third world. Also there is strange new characters, like the mysteriously overpowered Chinese woman who's superpower is that she's Chinese and is able to solo entire teams, despite being mid-tier according to the official tier lists (which dont even exist.) 

There is really no hope of appealing to any D&D or RPG fan. This is still true, throughout. It's one of those games you can't really critique, because you would just end up critiquing everything ad nauseum. There is so little that it does right, that it's actually a coincidence when you manage to find fun in it. 

It does not surprise me in the slightest, that WoTC, officially partnered with THIS mobile title, of them all. It's actually exactly perfect, in every way, in this regard. How do you make a game so f%*@#() BAD it can't even play itself? This is it, this is the absolute bottom of the gaming barrel, floating in the sea, in the grand interdimensional toilet that they call gacha gaming.

Not to understate, how the era involved Western consumer direct exposure to the third world, like breathing in raw sewage while stuck in traffic on your way to work.

There is a real "I designed this, it's my first game" amateurishness about it, which will undoubtedly remind the player of D&D and other D&D sub and off-brand products. But it also tries to "cash in" on D&D revival of the BG3 era of last couple of years, by adding obnoxious dice rolling everywhere. I've never clicked so much since playing Diablo. This is about the only connection to D&D or really any RPG. For the most part, it's a copy&paste Chinese "lower buyer" gacha some 'fan' bought to make his own mobile bestseller. 

Inexplicably, the devs of this masterpiece decided to compound it's problems by borrowing the lesser "multi-server, mmo-style, PoE season" system from the less popular titles in the gacha space. This skinner box feels a LOT like a testing ground for AFK devs to try ideas that they know for certain are doomed to fail, just to make sure they are right, in a live environment.

So, what's "new" in the ressurection? Honestly, I didn't notice much difference. I'm out of the loop on cheap mobile games lately, so I don't know the standard. It's pay to play and once the free currency runs out, you no longer have any reason to keep going. This may very much be the standard nowadays, for all I know. They really expect you to pay for nothing, and they promise not to deliver, cause they game is as unfinished as the beta was, for the most part. This is more or less the experience the first time around, only nice to know that anyone dumb enough to give them money got completely ripped off cause the reset came with a full server wipe, with a maximum of 10 pulls in compensation for playing before, even if you spent a million dollars.

The only real new thing is the new players I guess that are giving it a shot from a new perspective. Some of them seem like they are in the third world. Also there is strange new characters, like the mysteriously overpowered Chinese woman who's superpower is that she's Chinese and is able to solo entire teams, despite being mid-tier according to the official tier lists (which dont even exist.) 

There is really no hope of appealing to any D&D or RPG fan. This is still true, throughout. It's one of those games you can't really critique, because you would just end up critiquing everything ad nauseum. There is so little that it does right, that it's actually a coincidence when you manage to find fun in it. 

It does not surprise me in the slightest, that WoTC, officially partnered with THIS mobile title, of them all. It's actually exactly perfect, in every way, in this regard. How do you make a game so f%*@#() BAD it can't even play itself? This is it, this is the absolute bottom of the gaming barrel, floating in the sea, in the grand interdimensional toilet that they call gacha gaming.

I thoroughly enjoy this game but the shockingly poor pull rates are a major deal-breaker. 0.033-2% for a single legendary hero is insanely low. I tested with 100 of each roll dice, 1 legendary out of 200 rolls. The developers claim there is bad luck protection at guaranteed legendary on the 70th roll, but evidently this is not true. On top of that, P2W players are crazy over-powered. I think the global chat should be disabled because all I see is players from servers which are later into the game, sharing strategies with newer servers and not allowing those players to learn the game, test, discover and formulate their own strategies. If you spend the time to formulate a great line-up, it can be incredibly frustrating when other players simply copy-paste your line-up and don't take the time to develop the line-up further.
